title: Charming Vintage Photos Show The Waikiki Of Yesteryear
text:
Charming Vintage Photos Show The Waikiki Of Yesteryear Does anybody have a time machine? Landess Kearns Associate Editor, HuffPost Hawaii Posted: 08/26/2015 05:18 PM EDT 
Ah, Waikiki, land of swaying palm trees, carefully crafted mai tais , and blissful stretches of beachfront resorts. 
Even before Hawaii became a state in 1959, Waikiki was a beloved tourist destination. Since then, the area has changed and developed drastically. Modern-day Waikiki has evolved into a bustling shopping district with some of the best people-watching known to man . 
The Waikiki of today has its merits, but after exploring the historical photography collections of the Moana Surfrider and the Royal Hawaiian , two of Waikiki's oldest hotels, we're seriously wishing for a time machine. 
Below, a sample of photos, provided by Starwood Hotels and Resorts, that show images of a time gone by: Starwood Hotels 
Surfers ride the waves at one of Waikiki's famed surf breaks in the early 1900s. Starwood Hotels 
This pre-World War I photo shows the Moana Surfrider Hotel, built in 1901. Its first-ever guests paid $1.50 for their rooms each night. Starwood Hotels 
Surfers and their boards on Waikiki Beach. Starwood Hotels 
The beach at the Moana Surfrider Hotel, 1901-1915. Starwood Hotels 
A woman sits on the Moana Surfrider Hotel pier, 1913. Starwood Hotels 
The Royal Hawaiian Hotel's Coconut Grove, 1927. Starwood Hotels 
A guest and her daughter pose at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel. Starwood Hotels 
Beachgoers lounge on the sand in Waikiki, 1925. Starwood Hotels 
A woman offers a flower lei to a visitor, 1929. Starwood Hotels 
Aerial photo of Waikiki, with Diamondhead in the background,1930. Starwood Hotels 
Guests stand outside the Royal Hawaiian Hotel in 1928. Starwood Hotels 
Waikiki Beach, 1935. Starwood Hotels 
Military members spend time in a courtyard at the Moana Surfrider Hotel during World War II, 1942-45. Starwood Hotels 
This postcard photo shows people lounging in front of the Royal Hawaiian Hotel, also known as the "Pink Palace."
